text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^4 \rightarrow P_6[/mathjaxinline] be a linear transformation which is not into. What is the maximum possible dimension of the image of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: The transformation [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is into if and only if the dimension of the kernel, and thus the nullity, is 0. By the rank-nullity theorem, the dimension of the image of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is maximized when the nullity of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is minimized. Assuming that [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is not into, the minimum nullity of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is 1. Therefore, the maximum dimension of the image of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is [mathjaxinline]4-1=3[/mathjaxinline].
